;香港三条海底隧道的新收费对交通拥堵影响不大运输部长表示，但指出政策推出后数小时内，使用西线路线的出租车数量增加了 50%。

;

;运输及物流局局长林世雄观察西港的交通情况周三早上，隧道的三个路口的收费改革生效，以缓解长期拥堵。

;

;“今天早上，三个隧道的新收费系统运行顺利……穿过的交通三个港口过境点或多或少与以前相同，”他说。 “但这对出租车产生了明显的影响。例如，从午夜至凌晨5时，使用西区海底隧道的的士数量增加了50%。”

;

;林补充说，他相信一旦这三个隧道的交通水平出现明显改善的迹象，政府将在今年晚些时候推出按时间调整的通行费。

;

;两阶段安排的第一阶段将把使用西区海底隧道的私家车通行费从 75 港元（9.60 美元）削减至香港东区海底隧道及红磡海底隧道的收费则分别由25港元及20港元增至30港元。出租车在所有三个过境点将收取 25 港元。

;

;这一变化恰逢政府与西区海底隧道公司之间的协议结束，预计更多汽车和出租车将改道至不太繁忙的地区

;

;“香港过境点收费调整最初不会缓解拥堵”

;

;香港的士及公共小巴主席周国强协会预计，由于收费变得更便宜，20%的过海的士乘客会转乘不太拥堵的西线路线。

;

;“我相信的士拒绝收费的情况将会减少，因为它们会减少。”更愿意过海。这将缓解出租车司机和乘客之间的冲突。”他说。

;

;但周警告说，当局需要密切关注新政策是否会促使更多私家车过海并加剧拥堵。

;

; p>;

;今年晚些时候，政府将根据一天中的时间调整收费，以更好地管理交通流量。

;

;香港海底隧道将于周日采用新的电子收费系统

;

;周一至周六，早上7.30至上午10.15及下午4.30至晚上7点的通勤高峰期间，私家车在西区海底隧道收费港币60元，在红磡海底隧道收费港币40元，东区海底隧道。红磡海底隧道的新高峰时段收费是目前价格的两倍。

;

;所有三条隧道将于上午 10.15 至下午 4.30 期间向私家车收费 30 港元，晚上 7 点至早上 7.30 期间收费 20 港元

;

;

;商用车辆在三个过境点均需缴纳港币 50 元的费用。

;香港将于周三调整三条海底隧道的收费此举旨在缓解长期的交通拥堵。

;

;这一变化恰逢政府与西区海底隧道公司之间的协议结束，预计会有更多汽车和出租车使用这条不太繁忙的路线。费用下降。今年晚些时候，所有三个过境点的通行费将根据一天中的时间进行调整。

;

;在这里，《华盛顿邮报》将探讨新计划预计会对驾车者产生怎样的影响。

;< h3>;;

;私家车使用西区海底隧道的收费将由75港元（9.60美元）下调至60港元，而东区海底隧道和红磡海底隧道的收费将增加至港元30 美元，分别由 25 港元和 20 港元起。出租车使用所有三个过境点将收取港币 25 元的费用。

;

;香港将于 7 月 23 日起过海底隧道转用香港易收费系统

;

;

;

;稍后今年，政府将根据一天中的时间调整通行费，以更好地管理交通流量。

;

;周一至周六，上午 7.30 至上午 10.15 以及下午 4.30 至晚上 7 点的通勤高峰期间，私家车在西区海底隧道收费为港币 60 元，在红磡海底隧道及东区海底隧道收费为港币 40 元。红磡海底隧道的新高峰时段收费是目前价格的两倍。

;

;所有三条隧道将于上午 10.15 至下午 4.30 期间向私家车收费 30 港元，晚上 7 点至早上 7.30 期间收费 20 港元

;

;为避免驾车人士在价格变动前抢先过马路，过路费将在转高峰或非高峰时段每两分钟增减港币2元，直至达到最高限额

;

;商用车在三个过境点均收费50港元。

;

;香港商用车车主表示海底隧道50港元收费不公平

;

;

;

;运输署署长罗淑佩表示，调整后的收费预计要到今年晚些时候才能改善交通流量。

;

;“第一阶段收费差额将会收窄，因此可能会有一些司机从红磡海底隧道转往西区海底隧道。” “但第一阶段的影响很小。我们需要等待今年晚些时候实行时变隧道收费，才能看到实际的好处……并观察司机的偏好是否改变或交通是否被分流。”

;

;但是李耀佩香港汽车商会会长对新系统是否会改变交通模式表示怀疑。

;

;“西区海底隧道的通行费是最贵的，是其他两个繁忙过路口的两倍，”他说。 “新收费不会对分流三条隧道的交通有任何明显改善。”

;

;

;

;红磡海底隧道是三条隧道中最繁忙的，录得 1,850 万人次通过去年，私家车和出租车的双向过境量分别为 780 万人次和 780 万人次。东区海底隧道的私家车及的士双向出行人数分别为 1,540 万人次及 490 万人次。

;

;西区海底隧道的双向过境人数最少，仅有 960 万人次。小汽车和 330 万人乘坐出租车。

;

;新出行计划下，数十名香港司机跨境公路旅行

;

;

;

;副主席吴君星香港的士联会表示，部分出租车交通可能会改道西线，因为更多乘客可能愿意享受 25 港元的统一收费。他预测，出租车司机会希望使用不太繁忙的路线返回九龙一侧。

;

;“这是双赢，”他说。 “出租车司机可以避开另外两个路口的拥堵和排长队。”

;

;

;

;汽车协会的李先生表示，如果第二阶段未能显着改善交通流量，当局应该然后要么建造第四条隧道，要么使所有通行费相同。

;

;他认为，司机不会为了避免香港最繁忙的过海隧道出现拥堵而转而使用更昂贵的西区海底隧道。< /p>;

;“只有当所有隧道通行费变得相同时，才能缓解拥堵，因为司机可以真正选择走哪条路，而无需考虑通行费，”他说。

;斯里兰卡和印度通过大量的能源和技术巩固了长期的联系新德里推动在该地区发挥更大的战略影响力以对抗中国日益增长的影响力，尽管分析人士警告科伦坡不要过度依赖其更大的邻国。上个月，斯里兰卡总统拉尼尔·维克勒马辛哈 (Ranil Wickremesinghe) 与印度总理纳伦德拉·莫迪 (Narendra Modi) 会晤期间，双方就空气、能源和电力等领域的合作进行了交流。

;

;多个港口，包括斯里兰卡西海岸的科伦坡、斯里兰卡西海岸的亭可马里 (Trincomalee)。位于该岛国最北端的东部和坎克桑图莱 (Kankesanthurai) 即将开发，该岛面临着将其与印度分隔开的保克海峡。

;

;一条连接斯里兰卡和印度的石油管道以及一条高容量电力管道已达成协议电网，以实现该岛与更广泛地区之间的“双向电力贸易”，包括孟加拉国、不丹和尼泊尔——所谓的 BBIN 次区域经济合作倡议的其他成员国。

;

;两位领导人还同意合作开发绿色或无碳氨和绿色氢——一些人认为这是“未来的燃料”，因为它是利用可再生能源从水中提取的。

;

;鉴于斯里兰卡严重的能源短缺由于去年缺乏外汇进口燃料，分析人士表示，此次合作可以帮助该国转向更多的可再生能源，从而降低总体燃料消耗。

;

;但是，关键是不要过度依赖他们表示，外部电源。

;

;

;

;印度对斯里兰卡能源和港口项目的兴趣是其维持在南亚主导地位的持续战略的一部分，而中国最近一直在南亚占据主导地位。寻求影响力。

;

;虽然德里传统上与其南部邻国关系密切，而且也是斯里兰卡最大的债权人之一，但这个小岛国在印度洋的战略位置使其成为印度与中国的较量场

;

;斯里兰卡独立政治和能源分析师阿鲁纳·库拉通加 (Aruna Kulatunga) 表示，印度将斯里兰卡与孟加拉国和巴基斯坦一起视为“中国事实上的卫星国，因为他们已将土地出租给中国”

;

;库拉通加表示，该地区由中国经营的三个港口——孟加拉国的吉大港、斯里兰卡的汉班托塔和巴基斯坦的瓜达尔——形成了包围印度的“死亡三角”。

;

;“对于[印度]来说，这就像绞杀”，他说，因为这意味着德里需要投入更多资源来保护重要的海上航线。

;

;这使得德里加深关系的举措库拉通加说，科伦坡是寻求“心理安慰”的一种方式，因为它在北京已经控制的地区扩大了影响力。

;

;亭可马里是世界上最大的天然港口之一，目前没有为最现代化的船舶提供服务的设施。库拉通加说，德里坚持开发该港口，因为它希望“在印度之外、三角区内拥有一些东西”。

;

;本周早些时候，印度海军的库克里级护卫舰汉贾尔访问了亭可马里斯里兰卡港口为期三天，印度驻科伦坡高级专员公署称赞此次访问“增强了斯里兰卡海军的能力”，以应对地区海上挑战。

;

;斯里兰卡港口可能是中国的首要港口下一个海军基地的选择：报告

;

;这次访问是在美国 AidData 研究项目预测斯里兰卡汉班托塔港最有可能设立中国海军基地之际进行的，因为北京寻求扩大其海上业务

;

;曾在斯里兰卡外交部门工作的历史学家和学者乔治·库克 (George IH Cooke) 告诉《亚洲周刊》，最近与印度的交易更多地与政治参与有关，而不是德里与北京的竞争。< /p>;

;“印度无疑是[南亚]地区最强大的参与者，并且已经处于这个位置有一段时间了。这种地位只会不断增强。”库克说道。他还发起了 Awarelogue Initiative，这是一个旨在提高国际关系意识和对话的平台，重点关注斯里兰卡的外交政策。

;

;更多的相互依存和互联互通是一个积极的方面。新加坡国立大学政治学研究员 Rajni Gamage 表示，但实际上，印度和斯里兰卡之间的权力不平衡意味着这些举措需要很大的透明度，以便科伦坡的谈判代表能够参与其中。;

;“政治领导人可以使用‘危机’的语言来推动一些自上而下、片面的交易，”加马奇说。

;

;

;

;交易分析师库拉通加警告说，优先考虑政治和商业精英的利益可能会对当地社区和斯里兰卡社会弱势群体的需求产生不利影响。

;

;他引用了阿达尼集团的例子，该集团一直在利用印度在斯里兰卡的战略利益在于控制两国之间的电力供应。

;

;这家备受争议的企业集团 - 今年早些时候被指控会计欺诈和股票操纵 - 已经赢得了北部地区价值 4.42 亿美元的风电项目斯里兰卡。预计还将处理石油管道、与印度联合电网以及利用斯里兰卡绿色氢能等项目。

;

;阿达尼已承诺在斯里兰卡电网连接后回购电力，但库拉通加说：“这种情况永远不会发生，因为印度的电力生产单位较低。”

;

;“印度的地盘”：斯里兰卡敦促不要让债务影响德里的能源谈判

;< p>;截至去年 12 月，印度家庭用电一千瓦的成本为 7.9 美分，而斯里兰卡为 8.7 美分。

;

;这种不平衡可能会阻碍进一步发展库拉通加警告说，如果印度成为该岛国的电力净出口国，斯里兰卡的发电能力，特别是可再生能源的能力将大幅下降。

;

;“[斯里兰卡]将通过这条脐带与印度相连，只要他们愿意，他们就可以切断我们的联系。”他说。

;

;历史学家库克表示，虽然短期内加强互联互通对于满足斯里兰卡不断增长的电力需求仍然至关重要，但这一点至关重要以便该国开发替代能源，以确保长期自力更生。

;

;“这就是斯里兰卡将拥有多样化的能源来源，而不仅仅是一条管道，”他说.

;中国一家旅行社被指控利用女性顾客作为吸引男性顾客的诱饵” 7月26日，中国西南部四川省省会城市成都的一名女子在内地热门社交媒体平台小红书上分享了自己被误认为是寻找节日浪漫男顾客的经历。

;

;在题为“川西旅行社避雷”的帖子中，该女子发布了她与该旅行社销售代表对话的微信截图。

;

;该男子旅行社工作人员先问：“你打算哪天出发？”，女子回答：“八月初都可以。”我需要和我的朋友商量一下。”

;

;工作人员以为这位女士和她的朋友是男性，于是回答道：“8月3日报名的有两位美女，一位是1989年出生的，一位是1989年出生的。” 1991年。”

;

;他又补充道：“8月2日还有两只雌性，不过年纪太大了，可能满足不了你的胃口了。”

;

;这激怒了女子她立即​​怀疑旅行社利用女性顾客作为“诱饵”推销旅游团。

;

;她对旅行社工作人员说：“你觉得这很好笑吗？那两个女孩知道你说的话吗？您试图从他们身上赚钱，同时也将它们用作吸引客户的工具。你有没有职业道德？”

;

;从帖子中看不出来工作人员对此有何反应。

;

;这一互动很快引起了广泛关注，促使旅行社老板介入，声称因涉案工作人员说的是四川省通用的方言而产生了“误会”。

;

;“这位销售代表是四川人；可能存在沟通问题。我们从未利用女性游客招揽顾客。”该旅行社在飞蛋视频发布的声明中表示。

;

;该旅行社也发表了致歉声明。

;

;“这种行为是员工个人行为，不代表公司价值观。目前该员工已被辞退，绩效奖金已全额扣除。

;

;“将加强内部培训管理，欢迎访客监督。”

;

;尽管道歉，大陆社交媒体仍然对该机构持批评态度。

;

;一位在线观察者表示：“旅行社真的相信自己的借口吗？”

;

;另一位补充道：“方言不能被责备。很明显发生了什么。”

;

;“我在四川生活了很多年，从来没有见过有人用这样的方式解释‘不满足你的胃口’。”另一位评论者说道

;

;该事件也引发了人们对中国女性旅行者性骚扰问题的新关注。

;

;2019年10月，一名来自中国东部杭州的女性在泰国旅游时遭遇性骚扰导游以“她经常对我微笑”为借口，声称自己曾与他调情。

;

;2019年8月，一名来自东北的女教师在某旅游公司遭到导游骚扰。在中国西南部四川省峨眉山旅行时入住的一家酒店。

;在 2011 年好莱坞科幻大片《铁甲钢拳》中惊心动魄的最终打斗场景中，两个巨大的机器人在人类操作员的指导下进行了一场激动人心的拳击比赛。

;

;现在，由于中国工程师团队和他们的精彩创造——Qibbot，这一奇观已经变成现实。

;

; Qibbot 是一款远程操作的单臂机器人，旨在模仿熟练人类战士的真实动作，它从操作员那里获取线索 - 就像《铁甲钢拳》中的“原子”一样，由休·杰克曼 (Hugh Jackman) 饰演的失败者主角查理 (Charlie) 操作。拳击手引导他的机器人实现非凡的逆转。

;

;像查理一样，Qibbot 的操作员可以在场边控制它的动作，就像场边教练可能做的那样。

;

;Qibo 机器人公司开发Qibbot的中国东部山东省的一家公司最近在网上发布了一段演示视频，迄今为止已吸引了数千人观看。

;

;其中，Qibbot显示出令人难以置信的延迟或响应延迟时间仅 12 毫秒——这是远程操作机器人系统的新高度。它的创建者在公司网站上声称，它是“世界上最快的”远程机器人。

;

;快速远程操作机器人的主要技术挑战不是它们的速度本身，而是相对于操作员操作的响应能力。

;< p>;在体育比赛、打击犯罪、军事行动等场景中，机器人的响应时间至关重要，哪怕是最轻微的延迟都会造成严重后果。

;

;奇博机器人创始人耿涛表示全球超过 95% 的遥控机器人是为中低速任务而设计的，并且表现出明显的响应延迟，延迟通常超过 100 毫秒。

;

;相比之下，Qibbot 拥有令人印象深刻的低速度耿周二告诉《华盛顿邮报》，高速操作时的延迟仅为 12 毫秒，不到眨眼时间的 1/15。他说，这意味着操作员几乎感觉不到延迟。

;

;遥控机器人依靠多种因素来优化速度和性能。为了实现卓越的速度和极低的延迟，Qibbot 团队专注于解决机械和控制器挑战。

;

;对于 Qibbot 的控制算法，Geng 和他的同事除了传统的控制器之外还引入了一种新颖的“前馈”控制器反馈控制器。这种实时预测器可以预测系统延迟并提前做出响应，抵消部分由机械系统和虚拟现实设备造成的延迟。

;

;而不是旨在取代人类从事单调、劳动密集型或工作的主流工业机器人。他告诉《华盛顿邮报》，开发具有尖端功能的未来机器人（类似于波士顿动力公司敏捷的人形机器人 Atlas）来执行危险任务，一直是耿和他的同事的梦想和愿景。

;

;在全球范围内，只有少数机器人实现了超低延迟的快速遥控，但其体积较小，遥控装置复杂。这就是 Qibbot 的高处——高达 1.9 米（6.2 英尺）。

;

;它的手臂可延伸至 1.5 m，单臂版本的重量高达 140 公斤（307 磅）。

;

;“拳击机器人应该很大，”耿说。

;

;140公斤重的机器人快速移动所带来的雷鸣般的出拳、有力的碰撞以及地板振动将带来令人惊叹且略带恐惧的体验，他补充道.

;

;联合国峰会表示，人工智能可以比人类更好地管理世界 - 由机器人

;

;Qibbot 项目于 2019 年启动，该团队花了三年时间才开发出第一个 -一代模型。随后又经过一年的微调，Qibbot于6月份推出。

;

;耿表示，三人团队计划在今年年底前打造出升级版的Qibbot，拥有两只手臂，每只手臂有更多关节，动作更流畅。

;

;Qibbot 的创建者相信，快速移动的遥控机器人有潜力用于各种紧急和危险情况，如打击犯罪和军事行动，并且可以显着提高生产效率。

;The United States has formally invited China's newly reappointed foreign minister, Wang Yi, to Washington, the US State Department said on Tuesday, after Wang's predecessor was abruptly removed from his post by Beijing.

;

;China reappointed veteran diplomat Wang last week, replacing former rising star Qin Gang, who has not been seen for more than month – a mysterious absence after just seven months in the job that has raised questions about transparency.

;

;China's foreign ministry has only said Qin was off work for unspecified health reasons.

;

;The invitation to Wang was extended on Monday during a meeting at the State Department between US Assistant Secretary for East Asia and Pacific Affairs Daniel Kritenbrink and Yang Tao, Director General of the North American and Oceania Affairs at China's Foreign Ministry, State Department spokesman Matthew Miller told a press briefing.

;

;“In the meeting yesterday, we extended the invitation that had previously been made to foreign minister Qin Gang and made clear that invitation did transfer over,” Miller said.

;

;Miller did not say if the Chinese side had accepted the invitation but added that this was Washington's expectation.

;

;“We certainly expect that it is something that they would accept and is a trip that we expect to happen, but we have not yet scheduled a date,” Miller said.

;

;A spokesperson for China's Washington embassy said that in the “consultation” with Kritenbrink, the two sides had “candid, in-depth and constructive exchanges of views on China-US relations as well as global and regional issues of mutual interest”.

;

;“Concerning the high-level exchanges, both side have maintained necessary communication,” the spokesperson added.

;

;Exit Qin Gang, enter Wang Yi – what is behind China's foreign minister switch?

;

;A US readout of the discussion called it “candid, substantive, and productive” and “part of ongoing efforts to maintain open lines of communication and responsibly manage the bilateral relationship.”

;

;US Secretary of State Antony Blinken met Qin on June 18, on the first visit by America's top diplomat to China in five years. The US State Department said then they held “candid, substantive, and constructive” talks, and Blinken invited Qin to Washington to continue discussions.

;

;Blinken subsequently met Wang on the sidelines of a regional meeting in Jakarta in Qin's absence.

;

;Wang, 69, served as foreign minister from 2013-2022 as ties frayed with the United States to a point Beijing described as an all-time low.

;Former US president Donald Trump was indicted by federal prosecutors on Tuesday for his role in efforts to overturn the results of the 2020 presidential election, a move that puts Trump further into legal jeopardy as he seeks a return to the White House in next year's election.

;

;The front-running candidate for the Republican Party's presidential nomination posted on his Truth Social platform shortly before news reports that an indictment in the investigation led by US Special Counsel Jack Smith was imminent.

;

;The indictment included four counts, according to The New York Times: “Conspiracy to defraud the US; a conspiracy to threaten the rights of others; a conspiracy to obstruct an official proceeding before Congress; and obstruction of an official proceeding.

;

;Trump “did knowingly combine, conspire, confederate, and agree with co-conspirators … to defraud the United States by using dishonesty, fraud, and deceit to impair, obstruct, and defeat the lawful federal government function by which the results of the presidential election are collected, counted, and certified”, the indictment said.

;

;“The purpose of the conspiracy was to overturn the legitimate results of the 2020 presidential election,” it added.

;

;The federal indictment was the second that Smith's office has brought against Trump. In June, Trump pleaded not guilty to charges related to 37 counts related to his handling of classified documents at Mar-a-Lago, his Florida residence, after he left the White House.

;

;Last week, Trump was hit with new charges in a superseding indictment, including one asserting that he and two employees attempted to delete surveillance video footage at Mar-a-Lago last year.

;

;A trial date in that case has been set for May 20, 2024, in Fort Pierce, Florida.

;

;Smith's move in the latest case will provide more visibility into a wide range of actions Trump and his supporters took to obstruct the legitimate transfer of power to Joe Biden, the Democrat who defeated Trump by more than 7 million votes.

;

;That includes the run-up to the January 6, 2021 riot at the US Capitol, when more than 2,000 people stormed the building in a bid to disrupt the certification of electoral votes in Congress.

;

;Ahead of the indictment, Trump has regularly assailed Smith, the US Justice Department and the FBI, claiming on his social media platform Truth Social to be the victim of a “coordinated HOAX” orchestrated by his enemies to rob him of a return to the White House.

;

;The new indictment was only the latest development in Trump's legal battles. It follows an indictment against him in June for illegally retaining reams of documents with highly classified intelligence and obstructing attempts by US government officials to retrieve them.

;

;The indictment in the classified documents case, which included violations of the Espionage Act, was the first issued to a former American president by the federal government.

;

;According to charges in that case, Trump illegally retained reams of documents with highly classified intelligence and obstructing attempts by US officials to retrieve them. Additionally, he was said to have described a Pentagon “plan of attack” and shared a classified map related to a military operation with individuals who lacked security clearance.

;

;Trump has also been indicted in a state-level case in New York related to his role in a payment scheme to cover up a potential sex scandal to clear his path to the presidency in 2016. Trump has pleaded not guilty in that case as well.

;

;In yet another legal tangle this year, a civil court jury in New York found Trump liable for sexually abusing magazine writer E. Jean Carroll in the 1990s and then defaming her by branding her a liar; it ordered him to pay US$5 million in damages.

;

;Carroll's lawyers filed an amended lawsuit against him seeking US$10 million in damages to hold him liable for remarks he made after the verdict.

;More to follow …

;When Eritrean President Isaias Afewerki made a state visit to Beijing in May, he fondly recalled his time doing military training there in 1967 – just a year into China's Cultural Revolution.

;

;It was an experience that played an important role in helping Isaias lead Eritrea's 30-year fight for independence from Ethiopia, which it won in 1993.

;

;“[Isaias] remains fond of China and governs Eritrea and its relations with the outside world based on his decades of experience as a revolutionary guerilla leader combined with his interpretation of Maoist philosophy,” said a 2009 confidential cable from the US embassy in Eritrea, which was published by whistle-blower platform WikiLeaks.

;

;Isaias, who Chinese President Xi Jinping has described as “an old friend of China”, said during a meeting with Xi: “The Eritrean people will never forget the precious mental and material support the Chinese people provided for Eritrea's independence and liberation.”

;

;The Eritrean president is among dozens of current and former African leaders who attended Chinese military schools such as the People's Liberation Army (PLA) Command College in Nanjing – which hosts the highest number of African students.

;

;Another attendee was Zimbabwean President Emmerson Mnangagwa, who came to power through a military coup that ousted long-time ruler Robert Mugabe in November 2017. He was one of Zimbabwe's military chiefs who trained in Nanjing and was part of the core team in his country's liberation struggle.

;

;According to a recent study by the US Institute of Peace (USIP), the PLA Command College in Nanjing includes among its African alumni 10 defence chiefs, eight defence ministers, and former presidents Laurent Kabila of the Democratic Republic of the Congo, Joao Bernardo Vieira of Guinea-Bissau, Sam Nujoma of Namibia and Jakaya Kikwete of Tanzania.

;

;Many Mozambican military staff also trained there, including the longest-serving army chief, General Lagos Lidimo, as well as Ugandan commanders such as Major General Fred Mugisha, who led the African Union Mission to Somalia forces from 2009 to 2011 before becoming joint chief of staff of the Ugandan military.

;

;The college is one of the top Chinese places to offer training to a growing number of African students, something which has seen China become a major destination for African professional military education.

;

;Another military school, the PLA International College of Defence Studies (ICDS), sometimes has close to half its students from Africa, while the PLA National Defence University (PLA NDU) receives an annual intake of several hundred African officers.

;

;China arms sales cement its economic and security ties in Africa: study

;

;PLA NDU has a distinguished list of African alumni that includes former Democratic Republic of the Congo president Joseph Kabila and General David Muhoozi, the former commander of the Uganda People's Defence Forces and the country's current internal affairs minister, according to the USIP Chinese Professional Military Education (PME) for Africa study which was released earlier this month.

;

;Since 2015, Ethiopia has also sent senior officers who are about to become generals to attend graduate-level courses at China's NDU.

;

;Before Covid-19 struck, China would attract thousands of African officers to its military schools as Beijing engaged in a concerted marketing campaign to increase enrolment of Africans in its schools, according to the study.

;

;The study, which was conducted by Paul Nantulya, a China expert at the Africa Centre for Strategic Studies in Washington, said before the pandemic, about 6 per cent or 6,000 of the roughly 100,000 training opportunities China offered Africa every three years via the Forum on China-Africa Cooperation (FOCAC) were for military education.

;

;But the pandemic drastically reduced that number. During its summit in 2021, FOCAC, a cooperation platform between China and Africa, brought the training and education quota down to a total of 10,000, amid the uncertainty caused by the coronavirus.

;

;The study said Chinese diplomats have hinted that the pre-pandemic training levels will be resumed “as quickly as possible”. During his five-nation African visit in January, Qin Gang, China's former foreign minister, said Beijing was going to “accelerate the promotion of China-Africa physical exchanges, including military education,” as a top priority.

;

;Nantulya said in terms of military presence in Africa, China is outmatched by its Western peers across nearly every metric. The US, UK and France each have at least 50 military attachés in the continent; China has 21. Western countries have more than 50 bases and other facilities – the US alone has 27 military outposts – while China has one.

;

;In terms of African-based professional military education, too, China has a much smaller presence on African soil. Between them, France, the US and UK conduct at least 40 year-round programmes with defence colleges and academies, whereas China has PLA instructors and “training missions” in only two known countries, Zimbabwe and Tanzania, as per publicly available data.

;

;However, Nantulya said, African militaries appreciate the fact that China offers far more scholarships than Western countries.

;

;“African officers do not face the same vetting prior to enrolling in Chinese military schools that they encounter in Western ones,” Nantulya said.

;

;Dr Lina Benabdallah, a China-Africa expert and associate professor of politics and international affairs at Wake Forest University, said for the US, India, the EU and others who prefer to undertake training on African soil, their thinking is that it is cost-efficient.

;

;“Instead of flying in hundreds of officers to the US and having to pay for their room and board, it is much cheaper to send a team of trainers into these countries and do on-site training. Of course, knowledge of the local terrain is also advantageous for this approach,” Benabdallah said.

;

;But for China, she said, “there is a soft diplomacy objective that comes with inviting officers to China for this training”. Benabdallah said these officers get to travel across the country, see Chinese facilities, visit party schools, military bases, and get to meet many more people than if a team of five people from China travelled to their respective countries.

;

;The training in China nearly shut down during Covid-19, but as it returns to normal, African governments are taking full advantage, David Shinn, from George Washington University's Elliott School of International Affairs, said.

;

;“Increasingly, China is seen as an alternative source to Western training,” he said. Shinn added that as Chinese military equipment becomes more common in African militaries, it stands to reason there is a preference to train with it.

;

;“China has concluded, as Western governments did years ago, that providing the training is in its interest. It permits the strengthening of personal relationships and the ability to extend influence in African countries.”

;

;He said another appealing feature for some African governments is the fact Chinese training does not come with admonishments about the need for civilian control of the military and avoidance of human rights abuses.

;

;The training allows China to suggest a different political and economic model that it hopes will resonate in Africa. It also provides an opportunity to demonstrate Chinese military equipment and potentially sell it to African governments, Shinn said.

;

;“Better trained and more professional African military personnel who have had exposure to China will also be more inclined to protect Chinese personnel and interests in Africa,” he said.

;

;Ngboawaji Daniel Nte, a professor of intelligence and security studies at Novena University, Nigeria, said China has identified military cooperation and military training as key areas in its expansion into Africa.

;

;“China is strategically trying to export their military culture and power architecture into Africa. And part of this is to expand their military training to African countries,” Nte said.

;

;He said the training could be more expensive in the West.

;

;“Because of the cost implication, most African countries, conscious of the financial drain on their economies, will opt for Chinese military schools which offer virtually the same training as Western military schools for a fraction of what they are going to pay to the West.”

;

;He said some African countries are opting for Chinese military education because they are already indebted to China on several fronts. Some would also want to expand their memorandum of understanding with China to include a military cooperation exchange.

;Three of China's top electric vehicle (EV) start-ups reported record monthly sales in July, as a release of pent-up demand in the world's largest market for battery powered cars continues.

;

;The strong sales, which follow a price war in the first half of 2023 that failed to spark demand, have helped put the country's electric car sector back on the fast track, and are likely to offer the slowing national economy a much-needed boost.

;

;Shenzhen-based BYD, the world's largest EV builder, said in a filing to the Shenzhen Stock Exchange after the market closed on Tuesday that it delivered 262,161 units in July, up 3.6 per cent from a month earlier. It broke the monthly sales record for a third straight month.

;

;Beijing-based Li Auto handed 34,134 vehicles to mainland customers in July, beating its previous record of 32,575 units a month ago, while Shanghai-headquartered Nio delivered 20,462 cars to customers, thrashing the record of 15,815 units it set last December.

;

;It was the also the third consecutive month that Li Auto's monthly deliveries had reached an all-time high.

;

;Tesla does not publish monthly sales numbers for it operations in China but, according to the China Passenger Car Association, the American carmaker delivered 74,212 Model 3 and Model Y vehicles to mainland drivers in June, down 4.8 per cent on the year.

;

;Guangzhou-based Xpeng, another promising EV start-up in China, reported sales of 11,008 units in July, a jump of 27.7 per cent from a month earlier.

;

;“Chinese drivers that played a wait-and-see attitude in the first half of this year have made their purchase decisions,” said Eric Han, a senior manager at Suolei, an advisory firm in Shanghai. “Carmakers like Nio and Xpeng are ramping up production as they try to execute more orders for their cars.”

;

;A price war broke out in China's vehicle market in the first four months of this year as makers of both electric cars and petrol models looked to attract consumers worried about the flagging economy and how that might affect their income.

;

;Dozens of carmakers slashed prices by as much as 40 per cent to retain their market share.

;

;But the steep discounts failed to drive up sales because budget-conscious consumers held back, believing even deeper price cuts might be on the way.

;

;Many Chinese motorists who had been waiting on the sidelines in the expectation of further price cuts decided to enter the market in mid-May as they felt the price-cutting party was over, Citic Securities said in a note at the time.

;

;Beijing is encouraging the production and uptake of EVs to spur an economy that expanded by a below-forecast 6.3 per cent in the second quarter.

;

;On June 21, the Ministry of Finance announced that electric car buyers will continue to be exempt from a purchase tax in 2024 and 2025, a move designed to further propel EV sales.

;

;The central government had previously stipulated that exemption from the 10 per cent tax would be effective only until the end of this year.

;

;Total sales of pure electric and plug-in hybrid vehicles across the mainland in the first half of 2023 increased by an annual 37.3 per cent to 3.08 million units, compared to a 96 per cent sales surge in the whole of 2022.

;

;EV sales in mainland China will rise by 35 per cent this year to 8.8 million units, UBS analyst Paul Gong forecast in April.
